112520 S2468-8231(22)00406-0 10.1016/j.mcat.2022.112520 Elsevier B.V. Scheme 1 The synthetic procedure of the banana like NiCo/MgO-C catalyst derived from the tri-metallic Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs and applied for tentative one-step tandem reactions towards direct N-alkylation from reaction of functional nitroarenes with various alcohols. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 SEM-EDS (a,b) and HADDF-STEM analysis (c, d1–d5) of Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Catalytic performance of the NiCo/MgO-C, Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts for tandem reaction between the nitrobenzen and benzyl alcohol. Reaction conditions: m cat = 100 mg, n nitrobenzene = 0.81 mmol, P H2 = 2.0 Mpa, T = 200 °C, t = 10 h. Fig 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of the NiCo/MgO-C, Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts. Fig 3 Fig. 4 SEM (a, a-1, a-2), TEM (b, b-1, b-2) and HRTEM (b-3) images, as well as the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm (insets are the BJH pore size distribution and surface specific area result) of the developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst. Fig 4 Fig. 5 HADDF-STEM image and the corresponding EDS mappings of C, Ni, Co and Mg elements of developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Raman spectra of the NiCo/MgO-C, Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts (D and G represent defect and graphitic bands, respectively). Fig 6 Fig. 7 Ni 2p and Co 2p XPS spectra of the NiCo/MgO-C, Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts. Boosting performance for hydrogenation-alkylation tandem reaction catalyzed by banana-like MgO-based solid solution confined Ni-Co alloy catalyst: Fabricated by a MTV-MOFs templated strategy Weizuo Li Data curation Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Jing Wang Visualization Investigation b Dafang He Visualization Investigation Writing – review & editing a Guangyu He Supervision a Haiqun Chen Methodology Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, Advanced Catalysis and Green Manufacturing Collaborative Innovation Center, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, Jiangsu 213000, China Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, Advanced Catalysis and Green Manufacturing Collaborative Innovation Center, School of Petrochemical Engineering Changzhou University Changzhou Jiangsu 213000 China aKey Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, Advanced Catalysis and Green Manufacturing Collaborative Innovation Center, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, Jiangsu 213000, China b School of Chemistry and Materials Science, Heilongjiang University, Harbin, Heilongjiang 150080, China School of Chemistry and Materials Science Heilongjiang University Harbin Heilongjiang 150080 China bSchool of Chemistry and Materials Science, Heilongjiang University, Harbin, Heilongjiang 150080, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Developing highly efficient MOFs derived alloy catalysts for the one-pot tandem catalytic reactions remains a challenge. In this work, a novel solid-solution confined NiCo alloy catalyst incorporating carbon (termed as NiCo/MgO-C) with banana-like morphology has been synthesized via a self-templating strategy for directing pyrolysis of well-defined Ni-Co-Mg tri-metallic MOFs (termed as Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc, H2dhbdc represents 2,5-dihydroxytelephthalic acid organic linker). The developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst was applied for the hydrogenation-alkylation tandem catalytic reaction. Owing to the unique structural (e.g., highly dispersed, small size of NiCo nanoparticles, enhanced transfer of electron density) as well as NiCo alloy advantages, the developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst derived from Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs delivers excellent superior catalytic performance for the hydrogenation-alkylation tandem reaction to those of bimetallic MOFs (Ni-Mg@H2dhbdc and Co-Mg@H2dhbdc, respectively) derived catalysts (Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C, respectively). Notably, the tri-metallic Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc served as the precursor for synthesis of developed catalyst could enhance the reduction degree of NiO/CoO species confined in NiOCoO-MgO solid-solution during the pyrolysis process to some extent. Therefore, we anticipated that this tri-metallic MOFs-templated strategy may provide a facile and controllable way for synthesis of solid-solution supported nanoalloy catalysts for the other heterogeneous catalytic reactions. Graphical abstract A Ni-Co-Mg tri-metallic MOFs derived a solid-solution confined NiCo alloy catalyst incorporating carbon with banana-like morphology Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) Hydrogenation-alkylation reaction Tandem catalysis Alloy catalyst Templated strategy Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Hydrogenation/alkylated products (e.g., aniline, N-ethylaniline, N-phenylbenzylamine) have been extensively used as highly reactive transient intermediates for the synthesis of pharmaceutical agents, agrochemicals and dyes [1–6]. Among a great deal of N-alkylation reactions, N-alkylation of arylamines with alcohol is a significant one due to its simple environmental and economic perspectives [7–11]. For N-alkylation feedstock, the arylamines usually obtained from hydrogenation of nitroarenes catalyzed by the heterogeneous catalysts. Although various homogeneous catalysts (e.g., Co-, Pt- and Ru-based organic complexes) have been employed in hydrogenation/N-alkylation reactions with good conversion and selectivity, the drawbacks of stability, separation and recyclability have become bottlenecks of their extensive application in the commercial process [12–15]. Recently, many heterogeneous catalysts were developed and applied for the hydrogenation and/or alkylation reactions [16–20]. Based on the pioneers’ and our investigations results, the metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), coordination polymers (CPs) derived the supported catalysts exhibited excellent catalytic activity and selectivity for the various catalytic reactions (e.g., hydrogenation of nitroarenes, alkylation of nitroarenes) over the classic supported catalysts prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) method [21–28]. The enhanced performance of MOFs derived catalysts for various catalytic reactions was ascribed to the incorporation of heteroatoms (e.g., B, N, P) could considerably modified surface properties (such as acid-base, wetting, charge mobility, and electronic structure) of as-prepared catalysts [29–31]. More importantly, self-sacrificing well-defined MOFs for synthesis of carbon-nitrogen supported metal and/or metal oxide catalysts via one-pot direct pyrolysis not only straightforward affords precise control of the size of active species, crystalline structures, metal-support interaction, as well as composition of active-sites/support but also allows the integration of diverse functionalities (e.g., high specific surface area, unique micro/mesoporous structure) in one step [32–36]. For alloy-based catalysts (e.g., Pt-Co, Pt-Ni, Ni-Co), which exhibited outstanding performance than the individual metal hybrids due to the synergistic metal-interactions could generate intrinsic polarity and change the surface properties of individual metals during the reaction process [26,37–40]. Moreover, the solid solution (e.g., NiO-MgO, CoO-MgO) were also highly efficient catalysts for various catalytic reactions due to the capacity of MgO support not only could tailor the size of active metallic species and strengthen metal-support/-metal interaction, but also served as Lewis base to participate in the chemisorption/activation of acid molecules (such as nitroarenes, carbon dioxide) during the reaction process [41,42]. Therefore, it's highly desirable for synthesis of a multivariate metal-organic frameworks (MTV-MOFs) derived supported catalyst integrating alloy and solid solution effect for the hydrogenation-alkylation tandem reaction. Moreover, the investigation of Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc derived NiCo alloy catalyst for tandem reaction between nitroarenes and alcohols has seldom been reported. Notably, the prepared porous nano-/micro- catalysts with specific morphologies (e.g., nano-boxes, core-shell, nano-wire) could efficiently expose more surface active sites and improve the mass diffusion efficiency, further in enhancing heterogeneous catalytic process [16,32,43–46]. Herein, in this work, as depicted in Scheme 1 a, a novel tri-metallic Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs was designed and synthesized via solvothermal method. Furthermore, the Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs was selected as the precursor to prepare banana-like morphology of carbon-MgO composite supported NiCo alloy catalyst (termed as NiCo/MgO-C, Scheme 1b) via one-pot pyrolysis without using extra structure-directing reagent and template for the hydrogenation-alkylation of nitroarenes with alcohol tandem reaction (Scheme 1c). Various characterizations including SEM-EDS, HADDF-STEM, XRD, XPS and Raman were conducted to explore the origin of improved catalytic performance towards developed Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs derived catalyst for hydrogenation-alkylation tandem reaction in comparison with those of bimetallic MOFs (Ni-Mg@H2dhbdc and Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs, respectively) derived Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts. This MTV-MOFs derived supported catalyst may provide a new method for designing and synthesis of other supported catalysts for various tandem reaction. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals and reagents 2,5-dihydroxytelephthalic acid (99.9%, A. R.), Ni(NO3)2·5H2O (99.9%, A. R.), Mg(NO3)2·5H2O (99.9%, A. R.), Co(NO3)2·5H2O (99.9%, A. R.) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. The other chemicals were purchased from Aladdin Chemicals Co., Ltd. 2.2 Synthesis of Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc, Ni-Mg@H2dhbdc, and Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs The synthetic procedures of Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc, Ni-Mg@H2dhbdc, and Co-Mg@H2dhbdc precursors were according to the previous report with some modifications [47]: For synthesis of Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc: Typically, an ethanol/H2O mixed solution (1.8/1.8 mL) of cobaltous nitrate hexahydrate (0.073 mmol), magnesium nitrate (0.073 mmol) and nickel nitrate hexahydrate (0.073 mmol) was added into a DMF solution (30 mL) of 2,5-dihydroxytelephthalic acid (0.45 mmol) while being stirred for 3 h. Then, the mixed solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave (100 mL) and hydrothermally treated (120 °C) for 20 h. After the Teflon-lined autoclave was cooled down to room temperature. The resulting mixture were separated by the centrifugation, washed with the ethanol several times, and dried at 100 °C overnight. The preparation procedures of the Ni-Mg@H2dhbdc, Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs were similar with those above Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc except without introduction of cobaltous nitrate hexahydrate or nickel nitrate hexahydrate. 2.3 Preparation of NiCo/MgO-C, Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts The obtained Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc, Ni-Mg@H2dhbdc, Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs precursors were pyrolyzed at 700 °C with a heating rate (5 °C min−1) under flowing Ar and held at isothermal for 5 h, followed by naturally cooling to RT to obtain the final catalysts (denoted as NiCo/MgO-C, Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C, respectively). 2.4 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained by a Rigaku D/Max-3B X-ray diffractometer. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) experiments were performed on a GeminiSEM 500 instrument coupled with an element energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HADDF-STEM) images were obtained on the F200 instrument coupled with an element energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer. The Raman data were collected on a scientific Thermo DXR Raman microscope by using a laser with an excitation wavelength of 532 nm at room temperature. N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were performed on a Quantachrome Autosorb gas-sorption system to determine the specific surface area at 77 K. The XPS experiment was performed on an ESCALAB 250 system (Al Ka X-ray source, 15 kV, 150 W, 500 lm, pass energy = 50 eV). The binding energies of Co, Zn and N were calibrated according to the C 1 s photoelectron peak at 284.6 eV. 2.5 Catalytic reactions and product analysis The nitroarenes (0.81 mmol), alcohols and the as-synthesized catalysts were placed in reactor (100 mL). Before hydrogenation-alkylation tandem experiments, the reactor was purged with N2 and H2 to remove the air and N2 for three times, respectively. The reaction mixture were isolated by the magnet, and the isolated NiCo/MgO-C catalyst was washed with ethanol and dried before reused for recyclability measurement. The conversions and yields of reactions of hydrogenation-alkylation tandem reaction were analyzed by using GC-MS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs The crystalline structure and the contents of surface Ni, Co and Mg elements towards Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs were investigated by the XRD and SEM characterizations. As depicted in Fig. S1, the XRD pattern of Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs exhibits a high crystallinity, and all diffraction peaks are in good agreement with XRD patterns of the Ni-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs and Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs [48–50]. From the Fig. 1 , the SEM image of prepared Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc exhibited banana-like morphology with a diameter of ∼ 0.5 μm. Moreover, as depicted in Fig. 1b, the surface contents of Ni and Co are 0.7% and 0.4%, respectively. Furthermore, the distributions of Ni and Co elements on the surface of Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc was analyzed by the HADDF-STEM. From the Ni and Co mapping images, it can be observed that the Ni and Co elements were uniformly distributed on the surface of Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc without any agglomeration, which is favourable for the preparation of final NiCo/MgO-C catalyst. 3.2 Performance of NiCo/MgO-C, Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts for tandem reaction between nitrobenzene and phenylethyl alcohol Based on our previous reported studies, we found that MOFs derived transition-based catalysts exhibited excellent performance for hydrogenation of nitroarenes, tandem reaction between nitroarenes and alcohols, as well as CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [7,23,26,27,51–55]. However, the investigation of tri-metallic Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs derived solid solution confined NiCo alloy catalyst with specific morphology for tandem reaction between nitroarenes and alcohols has seldom been reported. Therefore, we investigated the tandem reaction between nitroarenes and alcohols by taking advantage of in-situ generated arylamines from the reduction of corresponding nitroarenes catalyzed by the Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs derived solid solution supported NiCo alloy catalyst (NiCo/MgO-C). Fig. 2 exhibits the catalytic performance of NiCo/MgO-C, Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts for tandem catalyzed nitrobenzene with phenylethyl alcohol. Surprisingly, all the three catalysts exhibited 100% conversion for hydrogenation of nitrobenzene, suggesting that MOFs derived catalysts could efficiently catalyze the hydrogenation reaction. For the developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst derived from Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs, which delivers higher catalytic selectivity (100% N-benzylaniline) in comparison with those of bimetallic Ni-Mg@H2dhbdc and Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs derived Ni/MgO-C (53.0% aniline, and 47.0% N-benzylaniline) and Co/MgO-C (68.0% aniline, and 32.0% N-benzylaniline) catalysts, indicating that NiCo/MgO-C catalyst derived from the tri-metallic Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs could enhance the catalytic reaction rate for the hydrogenation-alkylation tandem reaction under the same reaction condition. Therefore, various characterizations including XRD, SEM, HADDF-STEM, Raman and XPS were conducted to explore the origin of enhanced catalytic performance of the developed NiCo/MgO-C in comparison with those of Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts for the hydrogenation-alkylation tandem reaction process. 3.3 Characterization of NiCo/MgO-C, Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts The crystallinity phases of the as-synthesized NiCo/MgO-C, Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts were investigated by the XRD analysis (Fig. 3 ). As shown in Fig. 3a, for Ni/MgO-C catalyst, the diffraction peaks located at 44.5 and 51.8° corresponded to the characteristic of (111) and (200) reflections of metallic Ni, respectively. The other diffraction peaks located at 37.2, 43.2, 62.8 and 75.1° were assigned to the phases of NiO-MgO solid solution. For Co/MgO-C catalyst, the intensities of diffraction peaks towards metallic Co were rather weak may ascribe to generation of metallic Co with high dispersity or most of Cobalt species confined into the lattice of MgO forming the CoO-MgO solid solution (confirmed by the diffraction peaks located 62.1 and 75.1°) [56]. For Cobalt species confined into CoO-MgO solid solution with strong metal-support interaction (SMSI), which could not be reduced into the metallic Co during the pyrolysis of Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs. For NiCo/MgO-C catalyst, as depicted in enlarged section (Fig. 3b), the characteristic peak located at 44.3° lied between those of metallic Ni (44.5°) and Co (44.2°) indicated that the formation of NiCo alloy by employing the Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs precursor [26]. Moreover, the other diffraction peaks located at 62.1°, which lied between those NiO-MgO (62.4°) and CoO-MgO (62.0°) solid solutions, further supporting that formation of NiOCoO-MgO based solid solution catalyst using tri-metallic Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs served as the precursor. Meanwhile, the decreased lattice parameters of MgO contained in the NiCo/MgO-C (4.2103 Å) in comparison with those of Ni/MgO-C (4.2121 Å) and Co/MgO-C (4.2210 Å) catalysts suggested that the Ni2+ and Co2+ ions contained in Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs interacted with MgO forming the NiOCoO-MgO solid solution. In addition, although the contents of metallic Ni (5.3%) and Co (4.9%) (determined by the ICP) contained in NiCo/MgO-C catalyst were similar, the intensity of NiCo alloy diffraction peaks contained in NiCo/MgO-C was obvious higher than those of metallic Ni contained Ni/MgO-C and metallic Co contained in Co/MgO-C, indicating that Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs served as the precursor could efficiently improve the reduction degree of Ni/Co specie contained in NiOCoO-MgO solid solution without using extra reducing agents. Based on the previous reports, the alloy catalysts, especially for NiCo alloy, could efficiently enhance the catalytic performance of in comparison with individual Ni- and/or Co-based catalysts, which is a main reason why the developed NiCo/MgO-C prepared by the Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc exhibited the excellent performance for the hydrogenation-alkylation tandem reaction. The morphology and nano-/micro-structure of the developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst was characterized by FESEM and TEM. As depicted in Fig. 4 a, a uniformly banana-like structure of NiCo/MgO-C catalyst was successfully synthesized by the one-pot direct pyrolysis of Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs without using extra structure-directing agents. A closer observations (Fig. 4a1, a2) show that the surface of as-synthesized NiCo/MgO-C catalyst is rough, and contain numerous close-packed nanoparticles. Moreover, the surface elements (Ni, Co and Mg) contents contained on the surface of NiCo/MgO-C catalyst was measured by the SEM-EDS analysis. As shown in Fig. 4a-3, it can be observed that the content of Ni element (7.5%) is higher than that of Co (5.0%), which is consistent with ICP result (Table 1 ). Furthermore, the nanostructure of the developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst was examined by the TEM characterization. As depictred in Fig. 4b, b-1, where banana-like nanostructure was coated by the carbon species with a diameter of ∼ 70 nm. Furthermore, the NiCo alloy nanoparticles in developed NiCo/MgO-C were identified by the HRTEM (Fig. 4b-2, b-3). As shown in Fig. 4b-2, the NiCo alloy nanoparticles were highly dispersed on the MgO-C support. Moreover, the lattice spacing of the nanoparticles contained in NiCo/MgO-C catalyst were measured to be about 0.204 and 0.210 nm corresponed to the phases of NiCo alloy and MgO, respectively (Fig. 4b-3). All of which were consistent with above XRD results, and also indicate that the synthesis of multi-metallic MOFs (e.g., Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc) served as catalyst precursors was a feasible way for the preparation of NiCo alloy catalysts. Moreover, the micro-/nano- stucture of the Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts were characterized by the FESEM and TEM. As depicted in Fig. S2, the Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts exhibited similar micro-/nano- morphologies with that of develoepd NiCo/MgO-C, suggesting that the introduction of Ni2+ or Co2+ ions have no obvious effect on their morphologies. In addition, the mean size of NiCo alloy nanoparticles in developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst was 8.9 nm, suggesting that the tri-metallic Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs served as the precursor could generate the small size of NiCo alloy nanoparticles, which makes for the improvement of the performance of hydrogenation-alkylation tandem catalytic reaction. From Fig. 4c (inset), the isotherm corresponding to NiCo/MgO-C catalyst is type IV with H4 hysteresis loop. From the BJH pore size to NiCo/MgO-C catalyst (Fig. 4c inset), it can be observed that the developed catalyst contained two types of pores with abundant micropores and some mesopores. Moreover, the specific surface area of the developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst is 128.8 m2⋅g−1 (Fig. 5 c, inset), which could improve the dispersion of the generated NiCo alloy on the surface of catalyst to some extent. Furthermore, the distributions the elements Ni, Co and Mg on the surface of the developed Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs was examined by the HADDF-STEM analysis. As depicted in Fig. 5, the Ni and Co elements were uniformly dispersed on the surface of the MgO-C without any aggregation, suggesting that Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs served as the precursor could enhance the dispersions of the active Ni and Co species in the final catalyst. Moreover, the elements of Ni and Co in the developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst obviously overlapped, indicating that the formation of NiCo alloy. Moreover, the HAADF-STEM images and corresponding elements mappings of monometallic Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts are shown in Figs. S3 and S4, which also suggested that bimetallic Ni-Mg@H2dhbdc and Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs acted as the catalyst precursors could efficiently improve the dispersions of metallic Ni and Co in their derived Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts. All of which suggested that MOFs-templated strategy is a highly efficient way for preparation of supported catalysts with high dispersity and small size of active species. In addition, the surface content of Ni element (2.9%) is obvious higher than Co element (1.1%), which is consistent with above XRD and following XPS analyses (Fig. 7 ). The structural changes and surface defects in as-prepared NiCo/MgO-C, Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts were examined by the Raman analysis, and the results of I D/I G ratios were listed in Table 1. As depicted in Fig. 6, the Raman spectra of three catalysts exhibit well-documented D band (located at ∼1355 cm−1) and G band (located at ∼1580 cm−1), suggesting that carbon species contained in MOFs skeleton all could generate the graphitic structure during the pyrolysis process. Moreover, the decreased intensity of G-band peaks and successive up-shift I D/I G ratios (0.86 → 0.89 → 0.92) for NiCo/MgO-C, Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts revealed that more graphitic carbon were generated in NiCo/MgO-C in comparison with those Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts, which is favourable for improvement of electrical conductivity and charge transfer [8]. Notably, the developed NiCo/MgO-C showed the highest degree of graphitization with the lowest I D/I G (0.86) value, indicating a strong synergistic effect between Ni and Co on promoting graphitization [57]. All of which benefits for the enhancement of catalytic performance of as-synthesized for the hydrogen-alkylation tandem reaction. Furthermore, the surface compositions and chemical states of the as-prepared NiCo/MgO-C, Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts were analyzed by the XPS. From Fig. 7 , it can be observed that Ni 2p and Co 2p XPS peaks intensities of NiCo/MgO-C are weaker than those of Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C catalysts due to their low loadings of Ni and Co species. Notably, the shifts of the Ni 2p and Co 2p peaks of the NiCo/MgO-C towards higher binding energies due to the strong Ni-Co or Ni/Co-MgO interaction, as well as the small size of NiCo alloy. Moreover, as shown in Table 1, the surface contents of Ni and Co species were 0.73 and 0.71 at%, respectively, which is higher than that of Ni species contained in Ni/MgO-C (0.40 at%) and lower than that in Co/MgO-C (0.96 at%), which is consistent with EDS analysis (Fig. 4). All of which suggested that NiCo “alloy effect” facilities more Ni species migrated from the bulk onto the surface of NiCo/MgO-C catalyst, which makes for the exposure of more active Ni sites and improvement of performance for the hydrogenation-alkylation tandem reaction. The easy recovery (e.g., magnetic separation) and good recyclability of prepared catalysts have been regarded as vital criterions in heterogeneous reaction [52–55]. As depicted in Fig. 8 a, the developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst can be easily separated from the reaction mixture by a magnetic iron attributed to the strong magnetism properties of Ni or Co species. Moreover, the recyclability test of developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst for the hydrogenation-alkylation tandem reaction was also conducted. As shown in Fig. 8b, the developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity and selectivity for the hydrogenation-alkylation reaction for seven cycles of reused catalyst. The excellent recyclability of developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst for hydrogenation-alkylation tandem reaction may allow it to be a potential candidate for the heterogeneous reactions. From the above outstanding catalytic activity and selectivity of developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst for the hydrogenation-alkylation tandem reaction, we further investigate the general applicability towards the as-synthesized NiCo/MgO-C catalyst catalyzed nitrobenzene with diverse alcohols as well as ethanol with substituted nitroarenes in the hydrogenation-alkylation reaction (Table 2 ). As shown in Table 2, firstly, we investigated the performance of aromatic alcohols reacted with nitrobenzene catalyzed by NiCo/MgO-C catalyst. From the catalytic results, the developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst exhibits excellent catalytic performance towards the nitrobenzene reacted with benzylalcohol (98.6% yield) (entry 1). With the increase of reaction time reaction time (10.0 and 16.5 h, respectively) and temperature (210 and 220 °C, respectively), phenylethanol and phenylpropanol (entries 2 and 3) reacted with nitrobenzene, leading to 99.1 and 98.4%, respectively. Moreover, the reaction of nitrobenzene and ethanol gave the N-ethylaniline (84.0%) and N,N-diethylaniline (98.5%) (entries 4 a and 4 b ) when prolonging reaction time from 5.5 to 12.0 h. The reason why different weights of catalyst was used for cases 4 a and 4 b is that the performance tests are usually required to test it at conversions lower than 100% in order to avoid the excess use of catalyst. The scope of the reactions between nitrobenzene with other aliphatic alcohols were next explored (entries 5–7). The performance of hydrogenation-alkylation tandem reaction between nitrobenzene with other aliphatic alcohols decrease with the increased number of carbon atoms. Therefore, the optimal performance (99.1, 97.3, 97.9%, respectively) towards nitrobenzene with various aliphatic alcohols (butanol, pentanol and heptanol) could achieve when mediated the reaction parameters (reaction time and temperature). Finally, we also broadened the scope of substrates to substituted nitrobenzenes (entries 8–11), in order to vary the electron-donating/-withdrawing (e.g., chlorin, fluorine, and methyl) character of the substituents. From the catalytic results, the different electron-withdrawing/donating functional groups were nearly fully converted into their corresponding functional N-ethylanilines (98.2, 97.3, 99.5, 98.5%, respectively) when regulating catalytic reaction time and temperature (entries 8–11). Correlation above results of hydrogenation-alkylation performance and characterizations, the improved catalytic activity and selectivity of developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst for hydrogenation-alkylation is ascribed to great exposure of NiCo alloy active sites, highly dispersed NiCo alloy with small size exsoluted from NiOCoO-MgO solid solution and carbon species with SMSI, as well as enhanced transfer of electron density. 4 Conclusion A highly efficient solid solution confined NiCo alloy catalyst incorporating carbon (termed as NiCo/MgO-C) with banana-like morphology has been synthesized by direct pyrolysis of tri-metallic MOFs (Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc) for the hydrogenation-alkylation tandem reaction. Benefits from the tri-metallic MOFs-templated, the Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs derived NiCo/MgO-C delivers superior performance for the hydrogenation-alkylation tandem reaction in comparison with those bimetallic MOFs derived catalysts. From the characterizations and catalytic results, we found that Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs could efficiently tune the intrinsic properties of derived catalyst, and the synergistic effect of NiCo alloy, high specific surface area (128.8 m2⋅g−1), highly dispersed NiCo alloy with small size exsoluted from NiOCoO-MgO solid solution, confined effect of carbon species as well as well as enhanced transfer of electron density can exert crucial impact on enhancing the hydrogenation-alkylation performance. Notably, the tri-metallic Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc served as the precursor for synthesis of developed catalyst could enhance the reduction degree of NiO/CoO species confined in NiOCoO-MgO solid-solution during the pyrolysis process to some extent. Moreover, the Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs derived NiCo/MgO-C catalyst could efficiently result in the enrichment of high-active Ni species on its surface, which is also favourable for the enhancing the catalytic activity. All of which suggests that the developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst may serve as a promising candidate for other heterogeneous reactions. coredata.dc:description: Developing highly efficient MOFs derived alloy catalysts for the one-pot tandem catalytic reactions remains a challenge. In this work, a novel solid-solution confined NiCo alloy catalyst incorporating carbon (termed as NiCo/MgO-C) with banana-like morphology has been synthesized via a self-templating strategy for directing pyrolysis of well-defined Ni-Co-Mg tri-metallic MOFs (termed as Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc, H2dhbdc represents 2,5-dihydroxytelephthalic acid organic linker). The developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst was applied for the hydrogenation-alkylation tandem catalytic reaction. Owing to the unique structural (e.g., highly dispersed, small size of NiCo nanoparticles, enhanced transfer of electron density) as well as NiCo alloy advantages, the developed NiCo/MgO-C catalyst derived from Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc MOFs delivers excellent superior catalytic performance for the hydrogenation-alkylation tandem reaction to those of bimetallic MOFs (Ni-Mg@H2dhbdc and Co-Mg@H2dhbdc, respectively) derived catalysts (Ni/MgO-C and Co/MgO-C, respectively). Notably, the tri-metallic Ni-Co-Mg@H2dhbdc served as the precursor for synthesis of developed catalyst could enhance the reduction degree of NiO/CoO species confined in NiOCoO-MgO solid-solution during the pyrolysis process to some extent. Therefore, we anticipated that this tri-metallic MOFs-templated strategy may provide a facile and controllable way for synthesis of solid-solution supported nanoalloy catalysts for the other heterogeneous catalytic reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Boosting performance for hydrogenation-alkylation tandem reaction catalyzed by banana-like MgO-based solid solution confined Ni-Co alloy catalyst: Fabricated by a MTV-MOFs templated strategy
